unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Playing Solitaire and Winning on the Fourth Game
question_text:
Maria loves to play Solitaire on her computer and knows that the probability that she will win is $65\%$.
Assuming every game she plays is independent, what is the probability that the next time she sits down to play Solitaire, she will win for the first time on her $4^\text{th}$ play of the game?
solution:
In order for Maria to win for the first time on her $4^\text{th}$ play of the game, she must lose $3\text{ games}$ in a row, and then win a game.

We are looking for $p(\text{loss, loss, loss, win})$ or in the geometric setting we are looking for $p(x=4)$, where $x$ is the number of games needed to obtain the first win.

We can calculate this probability using the multiplication rule:

First, if $p(\text{win}) = 0.65$, we know $p(\text{loss}) = 1 â€“ 0.65 = 0.35$.

$$p(\text{loss, loss, loss, win}) = (0.35)(0.35)(0.35)(0.65) = 0.0279$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. It represents the probability of losing $4\text{ games}$ in a row and then winning on the fifth game.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. This is the probability that Maria will win exactly one game in four attempts and was calculated as a binomial probability.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. It represents the probability that Maria will win $4\text{ games}$ in a row.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. We cannot assume that the probability of winning a single game is equal to the probability of winning for the first time on the fourth attempt at the game.
